description: From Hindi–Urdu ख़ाकी / خاکی‎ (xākī), from Persian خاکی‎ (xâki, “dusty, earthy, earth-colored”).

adjectives.description: khaki (comparative more khaki, superlative most khaki)

entries.meaning: Dust-coloured; of the colour of dust.

nouns.description: khaki (countable and uncountable, plural khakis or khakies)

entries.meaning: A dull, yellowish-brown colour, the colour of dust.
Khaki green, a dull green colour.
examples: The English Government for a long time has used a type of pigmented dope cover, khaki colored by iron pigments and lampblack, which is called P. C. 10.

entries.meaning: A strong cloth of wool or cotton, often used for military or other uniforms.
(rare) A soldier wearing a khaki uniform.

(South Africa, derogatory, slang) A British person (from the colour of the uniform of British troops, originally in the Second Boer War; compare rooinek). (In this sense the plural generally is khakies.)
examples: "Frank, it's a khaki," I whisper, "keep straight on."

entries.meaning: (often in plural) Khaki clothing or uniform.
examples: The porter in going through the rear coach, which was almost empty, noticed one of the occupants, a muscular, soldierly man in khakies to be apparently asleep in his seat.
